summary: After religious spinster's (Katharine Hepburn) missionary brother is killed in WWI Africa, dissolute steamer captain (Humphrey Bogart) offers her safe passage. She's not satisfied so she persuades him to destroy a German gunboat. The two spend most of their time fighting with each other rather than the Germans. Time alone on the river leads to love.

reviews.content: This movie might move a little slow for people nowadays. But, just stay there and pay attention. It has everything you need. The character development is my favorite part. There's comedy, drama, excellent acting and the scenery is very real. Charlie looks like a rough drunkard, but turns out to be a sweet gentleman.  Rosie is a stout hearted, strong female character who takes no guff but, is also very sweet. They find adventure together under unfortunate circumstances that eventually lead to heroic acts which help in the war.
A film that brings a very exotic feeling to the screen. Bogart and Hepburn have great chemistry. What I didn't like was the religious undertones and lack of sensation building.

I found this quite a charming film - the two main characters, the upper class Rose Sayer (played by Kathearine Hepburn) and the working class Charlie Allnutt (played by Humphrey Bogart) make quite the unusual pair - their discomfort at being together comes across well but I thought it was sweet how they slowly started to care for each other, even though they so also get on each others nerves. The performances are pretty good for the most part, although there were one or two moments which I felt were a little over the top.

Oh and then there's a scene near the start, whereby Charlie is suffering from a very noisy stomach while dining with the upper classes - something I've often felt self conscious about (although not specifically being in the company of upper class people, mind you), so I could certainly feel his embarrassment then!.

Its mostly an enjoyable watch, with good performances and some good cinematography, so I'd recommend it overall.
Magnificent and wonderful, with two superbly acted central performances.

Classic romance/adventure story Both of the main actors have great chemistry. Charlie the river boat captain is very chrasmatic and really carries this film however its action scenes leave much to be desired even for something that was filmed in the 1950's but lets not forget this is the movie that inspired Walt Disney's iconic jungle cruise ride
Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn show their talent in the riveting adventure masterpiece.

The plot is a bit childish but is made up for by the two main characters providing constant entertainment. I feel like the threat of the Germans could have been used as a bit if extra suspense with maybe a German boat pursuing the African Queen down the river. Otherwise is a cute little movie that is entertaining.
A historic movie that won Katherine Hepburn another Oscar for a well made movie, I put African Queen as one of my top 10 movies!
An unexpected love story during adversity.

whilst the film contains two stars - Katharine Hepburn and Humphrey Bogart, there really is only one star performance in this film, Humphrey Bogart. I have never understood why he was so popular but he really shines in this film, his subtle humour works extremely well and carries the film. My only complaint is the German boat they are supposed to destroy. I was expecting a large battle ship but what we get looks more like a small tourist day-trip boat.
Classic film, everyone should  watch.

Although this is an Oscar-winning film, I can only consider it a classic that is so-so. The story was ok, with the common event being strangers to a romantic couple. The difficulties the characters experienced felt realistic and captivating. John Huston's directing of the film can explain how he wanted to use resources to give us an interesting story with right transitions. While this is not the best, it is not the worst film either.

I first saw this movie in 1951 when I was a young child. I saw it again today December 27th 2020. As a child, what haunted me about this movie was being shot at by the German army when going down the river.
In retrospect, the movie is an entertaining  romp by the leading male actor and female actor of the era. A little thin on storyline but very enjoyable all the same. You can never get enough of the brilliance of Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn.

Much like the Treasure of the Sierra Madre, this is a really great movie. Not as good, probably the worst John Huston film that I've seen, but it's still really great. I loved the performances, I loved the camerawork, I loved the story, I loved the writing, and I loved the ending. My only issues were some technical issues, that they probably couldn't do well in the 50s and it did drag a bit in the middle. But that doesn't matter I still really recommend.

AFI 100 Greatest Films - #17: This light and fun, yet definitely outlandish, romantic adventure immediately brought to mind Romancing the Stone or Indiana Jones. The Huston/Agee script was actually much sharper than I'd have expected given the fun tone of the movie. This demonstrates Agees admirable range as a writer and runs counter to my experience with him as a novelist (A Death In The Family), where the tone and subject matter were inversely darker than those found in this film. This film probably wouldn't have worked so well without two of the strongest possible leads to carry what is essentially a two person film, as Bogart and Hepburn are always a joy to watch. This is probably also another case of my inflation of a rating bc of the influence I recognize a film has had on those from the same genre coming after it.
The stiff morals and comic Germans, plus the portrayal of Africans hasn't aged well. The action is however fun. It's just a bit of a colonial era Boy Scout film. Very dated.
There are some pets that are obviously fake and rushed, but it's a whole lot of fun and influential none other less.

Here's a drinking game for you: watch The African Queen and whenever Humphrey Bogart uses "miss" to address Katherine Hepburn, take a shot.  You'll be unconscious by the twenty-minute mark.  As far as the actual movie is concerned, it's certainly entertaining.  The chemistry between Bogart and Hepburn seems genuine and the Africa setting is beautiful.  It's understandable how it was revered when originally released, but some aspects of the film have not aged well.  The music score is overbearing at times.  The acting leans towards corny, as evidenced by Bogart's animal imitations.  The special effects (check out the mosquito attack) are laughable, but typical of the era.  All in all, if watched through a 1950s lens, it's more than passable entertainment.
Without The African Queen there might still be Titanic, Indiana Jones and Romancing The Stone, but they would be entirely less classic.
Ok story and ok acting.

I honestly didn't know what to expect viewing this film, but I was pleasantly surprised. While it was a bit cheesy (I mean, all rom-coms are), I enjoyed the storyline and the comedic way that Rosie and Charlie handled the obstacles they came across.  The fact that they literally made torpedoes from scratch - I don't think that's actually possible, but it was funny. The movie was filmed in Uganda and the Congo, so we get to experience the diversity of life there, and it is amazing. And the ending - Charlie and Rosie accomplished their goal, and we got a kick out of it too. I enjoyed watching this and would recommend it to anyone considering it.

The African Queen demonstrates that even with a relatively small cast and small-scale impacts, adventure films can still dazzle. Bogart and Hepburn prove to be perfectly cast in their respective roles, imperfect protagonists and unlikely comrades in a fight they didn't ask for. (4/5)
Pure entertainment at its finest.
Love this film! A classic adventure film lots of fun and action
Surprisingly funny but I was left disappointed but how surprisingly basic it is. There are so many more interesting routes to take this concept to, but it just turns out to be a simple romance.
Academy award well deserved! One of the best adventure/romance movies I have ever seen!
Don't watch too many old movies but this one is pretty cool!

The African Queen is a simple story carried downriver by two iconic actors. This may not be the best role either Humphrey Bogart or Katherine Hepburn have ever done, but they play so well off each other that it makes for an enjoyable journey. The fact that they actually shot parts of this film in Africa added some authenticity, as well. I was pleasantly surprised by this movie.
Some films are just too hard to describe so the only thing you can do is recommend watching. This is one of those movies. And the thing is, it's just as powerful now as it was on it's release.

Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn are arguably the two greatest performers of all time. Bogart has proved his success with such roles as Rick Blaine in Casablanca and Samuel Spade in The Maltese Falcon. Hepburn has shown us her talents with The Philadelphia Story and Bringing Up Baby. Did they ever happen to make a movie together? Yes, they did. Was it any good? You bet your ass! 

The African Queen is a rousing tale of adventure and romance with two unlikely companions. Bogie plays a steamboat captain who agrees to take Robert Morley's sister, The Great Kate, back to civilization during the onset of World War I. In the process, they must fight for survival along treacherous waters.

The gin-guzzling riverboat captain is a great counter to the strait-laced missionary and the two stars make this a ride to remember. Besides the performances, the script probably shines the most. James Agee and John Huston, who also directed, have a great knack for writing crisp and smooth interplay between the two leads.

There aren't very many supporting roles in this movie, but Robert Morley makes the best of his small performance. He's actually quite memorable and he hearkens back to supporting players of older Bogart movies like Sidney Greenstreet.

Both leads received well deserved Oscar nominations and Humphrey Bogart finally won his big award. That should tell you that I'm not the only one who thought this movie was excellent. If you like stirring action with great chemistry from the stars, then you'll love The African Queen.

In my estimation, one of the best movies ever made...it's a riveting adventure story, but it's primarily a love story between two lonely middle-aged people who never expected to find it! The relationship allows both of them to find their true selves, and grow to heights they never imagined...!
Good movie, but wasn't the ending rather abrupt.  I love the fact that it was shot on location.

Watching it again...this classic stands the test of time.   Each decade I have watched it through the past 50 years of my existence, new subtleties come through.   So good on many levels .  Acting is the best
One of the best movies to watch. The absolute best movie stuff with the boat on the river in the 'rapids' and over the cliff...modern-day CGI is crap in comparison!

A classic for good reason, setting the template for adventure romances to come, the film's radical simplicity creates a sort of cinematic poetry where the onscreen journey down the river becomes a dual metaphor, both for the relationship between Rose and Charlie—a love beyond control, propelling the characters headlong into the precarious excitement of the future—and for the production of the movie itself, a storied shoot as dangerous and reckless and unwieldy as what appears on screen. Although an uneven ride at moments, especially the all too bouncy score, the result is strangely gripping and enduringly entertaining as the film bucks the sexist, agist, and colonialist expectations of its time with a sly sense not only of its technical achievement, but, thanks to the on their face phony performances of Hepburn and Bogart, a winking and artificial self-parody of the effort.

Quite charming.  A lot moreso than you would imagine, with these two characters at the start.  It's a testament to Bogie and Hepburn just how much they make you fall for them and how gradual and unnoticed it is.
Really good. It stands the test of time. Bogart deserved his Oscar for this performance.
This movie is a masterpiece. Perfectly cast.
Enjoyable,Hepburn and Bogart are very good together.
Beautifully filmed on location, with exceptional cinematography. Also Bogart and Hepburn are just 🔥
Simply the best romance movie ever made.
A thrilling adventure with a spectacular photography, although I have to admit I wasn't convinced by the romance part.

Boasting a sumptuous Technicolor, Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn elevate this enjoyable adventure classic with a charming sense of humor and wonderful chemistry-earning Bogart his one and only Oscar.

African Queen is a bit odd to me. Sometimes it plays like a capital-I "Important" movie, with its cinematography, performances and setting. At others, it's as light as a feather, especially in the jarringly corny and somewhat forced romance. Still, there's an ineffable joy to watching two titans work together so confidently and with such strong characters, and a better-than-expected ending. Decent if overrated.

It is difficult to understand the opinion of most that this movie is a classic. While the cinematography captures a locale not previously so detailed at the time, the value of a movie comes not only in its flash, but its substance. This was the worst chemistry, acting, dialogue and painfully long story I've ever been made to endure since walking out of "Dune" in the late 80's. I did not buy the transition of these characters from strangers to lovers, especially given the supposed spiritual roots of Katherine Hepburn's character. The most excitement happened during the rafting scenes, which comprised about 5 total minutes of the 1 hour, 45 minute snoozefest. It's an unbelievable premise with main character dialogue that seemed completely unnaturally forced and purposeful. One of the most overrated films I've ever seen.
Classic Movie with two amazing actors!  Bogart won a well deserved Oscar for his performance.  Must see film for any person interested in classic American Cinema.
An alcoholic couple goes on a romance-packed suicide mission

John Huston's film is a classic Technicolor adventure yarn that keeps its focus on the burgeoning romance between two mismatched misfits played by Humphrey Bogart (early 50s) and Katharine Hepburn (early 40s) and leaves more serious questions behind.  As they escape the WWI-era Germans down the Ubangi river in Bogie's ramshackle (and titular) boat, they need to work together to overcome many challenges (an enemy fort on the shore, a series of rapids, a broken propeller, an endless shallow and muddy river of reeds).  Bogie is rather rough and loves his gin whereas Kate is prim, religious, and a bit of a prude.  But as they fall in love, they compromise - this is a gentle older person's companionate love.  And they cook up a plan to blow up a big German warship patrolling an African river.  It's fun and the music (by Allan Gray) is jaunty and almost comical at times.  Of course, Huston notoriously shot this on location and engaged in big game hunting and lots of drinking during their stay in Africa.   Lauren Bacall (who doesn't appear in the film) was along to look after Bogie who apparently hated the shoot but won an Oscar.  To my mind, The African Queen is lighter fare, potentially even for kids (who are old enough to understand war); I would have preferred things to be a bit edgier but there is no doubt that the film belongs in the canon just for the unique pairing of the stars alone.
enjoyable story and great cast

My review focuses on the symbolism of the movie and on the characters, not on the plot. In the movie, "Rose" (Kathrin Hepburn) starts off as an uptight missionary woman, a clever but controlling woman. Throughout their ride down the river she controls everything that happens on the "African Queen" boat which is symbolized by her steering the boat throughout their trip and early on in their voyage by her emptying "Charlie's" (Humphrey Bogart) liquor into the river because he had exploded in anger and called her names in his drunken stupor. She later loosens up and reveals herself as "Rosie", an adventurous woman full of passion and courage and love who works just as hard for survival as Charlie does. Charlie shows himself to be an easy going guy who falls for her and agrees to go along with her wishes even if it means risking their lives. He has a double dose of courage in that he takes on all the challenges of the African jungle without complaining much and he takes on a headstrong woman and opens his heart to her. The movie's main message has little to do with Africa or the war. In fact, their rocky ride is symbolic of what happens in romantic relationships, and makes a statement that a good team is not one with perfect people, but one in which people accept each other the way they are, forgive each other and say I am sorry (Rosie later apologizes for throwing out his Gin), who know how to listen to each other, who put all their effort to help each other get out of a bad situation and who let that person steer (the boat) who has a bigger ability at saving them (or the relationship). And although their trip is full of challenges, they learn to laugh a lot and to enjoy the adventure. Because that is what decides if a relationship becomes a joyous adventure or a hard struggle: good teamwork.

Humphrey Bogart bagged his only Oscar, as a gin-swilling riverboat captain squaring off against Katharine Hepburn's snooty missionary, in John Huston's grand Technicolor tail of daring-do, shot on location in the bigger than life Congo.
Good classic story telling. Kathrine Hepburn is a class act, and Humphrey Bogart is the man. Two actors on a boat, and a good plot. Nothing wrong with that. Good concept, good execution.
Thrilling, well-paced Hepburn/Bogart adventure.

'The African Queen' breathes authenticity. Tumultuous at times but calmer at others, Bogart's and Hepburn's voyage on an African river is always an exciting adventure, surrounded by a colourful, luxuriant jungle. Yet, the brightness of Huston's film also lies in the remarkable, contrasting pairing formed by the two stars. 'The African Queen' is a very pleasant occasion to meet two of the most superb actors that Hollywood ever knew.

The africans at the beginning have no idea what they're trying to sing, lmao! Really interesting opening without saying much but showing plenty. You got the white Methodist Christians putting a church in the middle of the jungle trying to put their beliefs and religion on the indigenous people. And then out of nowhere, Bogart's character comes on a rickety old boat with no inhibitions and probably a very independent man.

Insane how the Germans are making the africans fight against their own people. Watching Katharine Hepburn try to get up into the boat from the water was funny. It was really nice to see how they both helped out each other as if they were in a serious relationship. So sweet to see how their relationship progresses and how comfortable they become with each other.

Pretty damn good effects being used that are well ahead of it's time. I really like that they filmed in Africa. 

Overall, pretty good adventure and romance move. Though not my cup of tea, I found the chemistry and acting interesting. The story was kind of ehh, I was basically waiting for the movie to be over. I don't see how Rotten Tomatoes could have given it a 100%, that's just ridiculous. I think a more fitting rating would be an 83%.

Perhaps a 1951 film isn't everyone's cup of tea but with such good ratings I decided to give it a go. Glad I did.
The film is based on C.S. Forester's 1935 novel of the same name and stars lead actors Humphrey Bogart as tramp steamer captain Charlie Allnut and Katherine Hepburn as religious missionary spinster Rose Sayer.
The film is supposedly set in German occupied East Africa during World War One.
The film begins with Rose actually married to a religious missionary in some country in East Africa. Her husband dies shortly after their village is attacked by German invaders.
Charlie delivers the post and supplies to the village by a steam boat The African Queen.
Charlie is a rather scruffy, Gin drinking American where as Rose is a clean living, moral, English lady.
The only means of escape is down river facing numerous obstacles along the route such as perilous rapids, a German fort on the bank and a gunship patrolling the lake at the end of the river.
Bogart won his sole Academy Award for Best Actor for his role.
The film was shot in glorious Technicolor photography that really shows the great location shoots.
The film has a great feel good feeling that I would recommend to anyone put off by the age of the film.

Another overrated classic film.  Sure, Humphrey Bogart had some amusing lines in The African Queen but Katherine Hepburn's character was simply irritating.  Starts out as stuck up and judgmental and then turns into a fawning butt kisser and ruins Bogart as well.  The journey downriver was interesting in parts but dull in others so a mixed bag at best.  Then the conclusion... absurd is one way to put it, the final five minutes got nothing but a roll of the eyes from me.  I don't get the appeal, is it because it stars two of the biggest names of the time?  Not enough for me.
Seminal romantic adventure that makes up for it's more dated areas by having fully resourceful character.

Ok the good, beautiful scenery and set pieces are on display, Humphrey Bogart is always a plus, and the plot is interesting enough. However, it fell into massive melodramatic cheese in its third act, and there were on very strange scene where Bogart was impersonating jungle animals. The rest of the film was not bad, although not very exciting either, and the ending left a lot to be desired in my opinion

The African Queen was never going to be anything other than a classic film.  With John Huston directing legendary actors Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn, it was only a matter of laying some dialogue down on a script and letting these three sail their way straight to the top of the box office.

Parts of the movie feel dated, of course, as this movie hits all the usual notes of an Old-Timey Adventure Rom-Com.  

However, the acting is nothing short of superb.  Ultimately it was ol' Bogie who won an Oscar for his performance in the movie, but Hepburn was equally charismatic, deserving of the same award had she not gone up against Vivien Leigh in A Streetcar Named Desire.
Great story with great actors.  An underdog love story with a happy ending.
A charming production
Featuring an iconic and entertaining pairing of Bogart and Hepburn, "The African Queen" is half wartime period drama, the other excitement filled adventure.
An endearing and ensuring classic thanks to the charm of Hepburn and Bacall. There's a reason they're two of the greatest actors film actors.
This movie is a must for anyone at any age .
Great interaction between boast and Hepburn.
Bogie's great (obviously) but the actual film hasn't held up too well. Still good, though.

Heard so much about this movie and have finally seen it. Excellent script, casting, portrayals, and cinematography. If anything, this could have been 20 minutes longer. Shows what effect a distant war can have when a few become patriotic - or romantic.
Well-filmed, detailed, and charmingly acted, a 50s star-led Hollywood film such as this still doesn't go by without its signs of the time.

Bogey and Hepburn at their best....a wonderful film and Bogart (AT LAST) got a deserved oscar. In my opinion, this should have been his second, the first beibg for his marvellous performance in "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre". Well, Hollywood is a strange place....!! But this movie is just a delight in so many ways. Bogart is magnificent. Hepburn is magnificent. An actor and actress at their height. My favourite scene is when they have "tea" and Bogey's rumbling stomach interrupts the otherwise "genteel" afternoon tea in true English fashion so beloved of Hollywood. A great moment in a great movie.
This sixty-four year old movie has not lost any of it's charm! I loved it again.
The real meaning of Humphrey Bogart www.tinyurl.com/z5a5vgg

One of the most overrated movies of all time.  The writing is horrible.  The special effects were comical, which isn't a good thing.  The plot is implausible at best.  Just not a very good movie, in spite of it's sterling reputation.
Classical adventure and romance, amazing performances from our two leads. You need not much more.
It is really impossible to not have so much fun watching The African Queen, especially with Hepburn & Bogart on screen together.
Parents took me to see this, i think.
Yes, Bogart and Hepburn make a great team in a great movie!
A great movie and a definite class. Can be somewhat boring a little bit but still worth the watch.
WW1 breaks out & turns everybody into a combatant to the far flung reaches of the earth & all adventure & heroics that come with war.
Just saw it again. Still one of my all time favs.

Charlie: "We can't do that!"

Rose: "How do you know? You never tried it."

Charlie: "Well, yeah, but I never tried shooting myself in the head neither."
its a pretty good movie

The relationship between Bogart and Hepburn runs heavy on schmaltz, but her iron-willed determination and some great set pieces make a winner. Plus, the making of the film inspired a pretty solid Clint Eastwood movie thirty-odd years later.

It's ok. Enjoyable but it hasn't aged that well.  
The acting and the characters are good for the most part. 
Sit down with a loved one and enjoy.

A good solid movie, very well made. Love the chemistry between Hepburn and Bogart. Worth seeing just for that. It would be made completely different today, which is another reason to appreciate this film.

A very entertaining and exciting adventure shot on location in Africa in glorious Technicolor and with a wonderful chemistry between Hepburn and Bogart - she as a smart, determined and strong-willed woman and he in a hilarious performance that granted him his only Oscar.
Bogart and Hepburn are excellent, with Huston also on top form. This is a classic adventure. But how this did not get a Best Picture Oscar nomination we will never know.

A really good classic romantic adventure movie, it moves along through various plot twists and beautiful cinematography of Africa. Granted some parts are a little dated, like some of the action scenes with the fake backdrop, the story and acting is pretty darn good and some scenes are inspired by later movies. I was actually kinda surprised they wound up liking each other, but opposites attract and after what they go thru together it makes sense. The setting of Africa and being on this crazy boat trip is actually quite romantic. Sometimes Hepburn's character was so stubborn and uptight, but she eventually lets her guard down some and she has a good heart under it all. Bogart doesn't play his usual cooler than cool self and plays a character as cuddly as Bogart can get. They both made me laugh in this film. I loved both characters and enjoyed their interesting match together and watching their love story progress.
A cheesy, ridiculous, but well-directed rom-com.
Of course, special effects and music are dated, but certainly a timeless classic.

The African Queen is the story of a rough-around-the-edges riverboat captain and a straight-laced missionary in Africa who are basically run out of their homes by the Germans in WWI. As a result they decide to retaliate by using the riverboat as a weapon to try and sink a German warship. Not enough can be said about the performances from Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn. I don't think I'm spoiling much by saying that over time they fall in love (you can kind of see that coming from their very first scene together because the movies love opposites-attract relationships.) What was remarkable about their performances in The African Queen is that I actually bought it. While there was indeed one moment when they suddenly began to kiss and they spoke differently to one another from then on, I actually saw the slow progression leading up to that point so they earned that breakthrough moment. It felt right, as though they were 2 people genuinely forming a connection as they struggle through this difficult ordeal. You probably couldn't get away with this in modern cinema, but it was also a treat to see this love story take place between an older couple who were covered in dirt and grime half the time. It gave the story a more authentic feeling, as opposed to the young hot bodies they would feel compelled to use nowadays.

The entire film is kind of episodic. As they travel down the river they go through one ordeal, conquer it, and then move on to the next. Some of these scenes are more interesting than others, but I have particular affinity for the ones that deepen the relationship between the two characters. One of the oddest choices that they made in the movie is that almost every sentence the 2 characters say to one another is preceded by the name (or some other title) for the person they are addressing. It just seems so strange hearing "Mr. Allnut" about 50 times in a matter of 30 minutes of film. It could be somewhat grating on the nerves, particularly since it's just 2 people. I think they make that pay off by having their titles for each other slowly transition into more endearing terms, but they went a little overboard. The story's conclusion also feels a bit far-fetched and convenient, but it is one of those endings that makes you all warm and fuzzy, so I don't mind. It's also worth mentioning that, considering the available technology of the time, some of the shots they captured are spectacular. There is one zoom out that is simply amazing and tells so much without using a word. Even the rear-projection backgrounds are hidden relatively well. The African Queen is a classic film that I can strongly recommend, because I think the story holds up, and the acting is just what you need in a film that is almost entirely 2 people alone floating down the river.

One of the great adventure stories is told beautifully by director John Huston, with Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn forming an unlikely partnership to sink a German warship in Africa during WWI. The plot, though, is secondary to the pure joy of watching these two giants work together at the top of their game. Jack Cardiff's Technicolor cinematography is breathtaking.

It is difficult to understand the opinion of most that this movie is a classic.  While the cinematography captures a locale not previously so detailed at the time, the value of a movie comes not only in its flash, but its substance.  This was the worst chemistry, acting, dialogue and painfully long story I've ever been made to endure since walking out of "Dune" in the late 80's. I did not buy the transition of these characters from strangers to lovers, especially given the supposed spiritual roots of Katherine Hepburn's character. The most excitement happened during the rafting scenes, which comprised about 5 total minutes of the 1 hour, 45 minute snoozefest. It's an unbelievable premise with main character dialogue that seemed completely unnaturally forced and purposeful. Once of the most overrated films I've ever seen.
This Movie Was Also One Of Humphrey Bogart's Great Roles .   This Film Was A Great One Because It Blended Romance,  Drama,  Adventure And Action .
Bogart and Hepburn do a good job.  I am so used to Bogart in Maltese Falcon and Casablanca that I forgot he was in this.

Je ne sais pas si c'est de le revoir aujourd'hui mais ce film m'a semblé d'un ridicule excessif. L'histoire est niaise, c'est certainement pas la meilleur interprétation des acteurs principaux, ni le meilleur film de Huston, c'est bourré de faux-raccords et de figurants qui se ratent etc... Enfin, ce n'est plus le souve,ir que j'en avais quand je l'ai vu gamin. En film des 50's, y'a beaucoup mieux.
This movie was ahead of its time and is very entertaining
loved it ,a  true classic

El gran John Huston nos ofrece una magistral y encantadora historia de romance y aventuras protagonizada por los inmortales Humphrey Bogart y Katharine Hepburn.  ¿Qué más puede pedir un fanatico del cine?  La Emoción, el humor, los diálogos estupendos y las sólidas actuaciones y dirección, hacen de "The African Queen" un clásico inmortal en refulgente Technicolor.
It's often slow, but the acting is incredible and the story is engaging.
Katherine Hepburn and Humphrey Bogart! What more can you want?

Despite the story's simplicity it's a fairly entertaining, adventurous ride down the river, with great-as-always acting by Katharine Hepburn and Humphrey Bogart. The ending seems a bit implausible, but if you're able to overlook that you will not be disappointed by "African Queen".
The African Queen... starring Humphrey Bogart? What's next, The Mexican starring Brad Pitt? But seriously, this is a charming adventure film with two actors whose performances elevate the material.

Humphrey Bogart again teams up with director John Huston, and stars along Katherine Hepburn. Both give fine performances boosted by the excellent direction by Huston. It is a great jungle adventure film that has two great performances and really knows how to keep the action coming without forgetting to take time to breath, something that has long been forgotten in many modern adventure films.  Good stuff.

Very good. 7.7/10. B+.


It does stray into dullness after a while, but it's still able to hold the audience's attention for two-thirds of its run-time while carrying a wonderful script and a great performance by Bogart.
Monumental. So, Charlie wasn't as hard-boiled as we may have thought, and Ms. Hepburn is gorgeous even covered in mud.
Nothing special about this film but still worth watching.

The film's soul is represented by the titular boat, both run by Bogart's performance in this fun ride that 's probably one of the best adventure films of all time. Also to note, it was an inspiration for the Jungle Cruise ride. (A-)

(Full review coming soon)

It's not one of my favorite classics, but The African Queen is an undeniably revolutionary movie that has defined the adventure genre since its release and it will continue to be a landmark achievement in the years to come. Humphrey Bogart gives an excellent performance as very well-developed character and leads the movie to its fantastic ending.
Of all the C.S. Forester that could have been adapted, America chose this over any Hornblower book? For shame.

John Huston marshals two Hollywood juggernauts (Bogart and Hepburn) in an African cruise on a riverboat (named THE AFRICAN QUEEN) set under the dawn of WWI, with the outlandish aim to torpedo a German dreadnought as a suicide attack.  

Opening up with close-up shots perusing indigenous dwellers out of  exoticism, with an accompanying carol of psalm conducted by Rev. Samuel Sayer (Morley) and his sister Rose (Hepburn) in the 1st Methodist Church in Kungdu, which reeks of condescending Pharisaism since none of the locals have a clue of what they are parroting, and the unhealthy allusion of them to a bunch of predators when the boat owner Charlie's (Bogart) unfinished cigarette is up for grabs doesn't ameliorate the revulsion albeit its intention of being funny, nevertheless Bogart's belly is just as musical as his singing. 

Luckily soon we embark on an adventure strictly includes only Rose and Charlie, it's never too late to fall in love, after the initial distinction around Rose's starry-eyed strategy, the flame of romance is kindled during a perilous passage with rapids. The thrill of riding the waves must stir up an old maiden's passion, the two-hander between Bogart and Hepburn is tremendously entertaining to watch, Bogart plays against his usual detached sangfroid, totally unreserved as a down-to-earth ilk, it is quite refreshing to know this role capped him an Oscar statue, when he imitates a roaring hippopotamus, the joy is tangible and it is a precious moment for Boart's screen image; Hepburn is at the top of her game as well, her appellation to Charlie changed from Mr. Allnut to dear is handled with a heartwarming vignette, and she is also the trailblazer who pioneers a progressive view as a fearless woman, challenges Bogart to the final assail gallantly meanwhile her tender moment with the man she loved is truly touching. The film is also a taxing endeavor in a physical sense, frowzily dressed under the sizzler, all the river turbulence they have to endure (although it is too dangerous to be shoot live on-set, the post-produced and recreated effect is just passable), slogging through the reed-rampant water area by trawling the boat manually, not to mention the fake mosquitoes and leeches (most of the crew were under the weather during the shooting). 

Near the coda, Houston deftly injects some gallows humor into their capture by the German navy, but the final twist is merely ludicrous, the capsize is exerted with a slapdash hurry, anyway, it is a genuine romantic exploit can woo a massive fun-seeking, love-hankering viewers plus many non-German patriots and for Huston and his team, it was a lavish hunt for novelty paid by the company and the inception of a long-standing friendship between Lauren Bacall and Katharine Hepburn.

Humphrey Bogart and Katherine Hepburn gave one of their best performances in this film, and  this is great because it took place towards the end of their careers, rather than the beginning. What stood out to me is Bogart's appearance; he looked sickly, and this was due to health problems which led to his death in 1957. However, he truly gave a terrific performance which earned him to a well deserved Oscar.
I didn't know Bogart could do comedy. Wonderful movie, and, as I understand it, was an inspiration for The Jungle Cruise.

This was a very ambitious film for its time as it tried to blend in filming on location and filming in studio which was unheard of at the time as most films were just done on the studio backlot.  It mostly succeeds but some of the bigger set pieces are considerably dated, it did not affect my enjoyment of the film though.  Hepburn and Bogart are just great as always and they have great chemistry. There is not much to this film as all it is is 2 people trying to sink a German warship.  It plays out in a predictable fashion, but the 2 stars handle it so well.  Overall, an enjoyable film.

Sound: Excellent environmental sound. Great orchestral score. Great sound editing. Great use of chararacters who cannot sing, singing. 
90/100 

Technical: Processed shots work well. One mismatched film stock shot. Excellent exposure for equatorial Africa and matching for the studio shots. Good use of framing. 
95/100 

Narrative: Characters well established while the story remains in motion. The narrative is moved by tensions between the characters until they reach their goal. This form becomes the norm for romantic comedies, which this is. 
100/100 

Character/Acting: Excellent dialog with great tension and arc between Bogart and Hepburn. The river and the boat become characters too. Good humorous takes and iconic shots. 
100/100 

Did I like it: Yes, very funny. A highly appreciable and funny classic film. 
85/100 

Artistic merit: an excellent example of cinema with high quality performances and still remains simple; two people a boat and a river. 
100/100 

Total score 95/100

Two sexually frustrated (and repressed) people with little to no education (or adventure) in life bond after being forced onto a lifeboat. After Rose's life as the maiden-lady sister of a missionary comes to close after 10 years of servitude,  she sees her one chance to live to the fullest.  Her ideas make little sense and she breaks-in her companion like one would a horse. Something that seems like love happens to them, but it is entirely situational and relies on Rose's dominating persona. All the while, Charlie is given something he believes to be a purpose. In the end, they both seem to come together and "be in love" due to the magic of Stockholm syndrome. As the fiim ends, they seem to have lost all semblance of self (and sanity). While I doubt the film was made with said intentions, it works as a sad commentary on repression and the absurdity of the missionaries. Once havoc hits the African village, their shallow "care" for the natives is not only abandoned, but completely unaddressed. This film, in my opinion, works best when viewed through modern eyes...it's real pretty though. :P
Overall a good film. It had it's moments.
Though some of the dialogue is cliche by today's cinematic standards, The African Queen proves that Bogart and Hepburn were still strong even when out of their prime.
Really enjoyed this one. Loved the acting. Cheesy ending, but that's OK. Amazing how much just two people were on screen.

The African Queen (John Huston, 1951)
[originally posted 13Jul2000]

The best way to watch The African Queen is just after watching White Hunter, Black Heart. Once you've seen the shenanigans that accompanied the putting together of this picture, it becomes all the more enchanting. (One wonders how Huston was convinced to film pieces of it in England, however, since he insisted on shooting the whole thing in Africa, and Viertel didn't elucidate that point in the film version of WHBH; if it's in the book I haven't gotten that far yet.)

For those unfamiliar with the plot (if you've been living in a cave for the last fifty years): A missionary (Robert Morley) and his strait-laced sister (Hepburn) are ministering to natives in what was known in 1918 as German East Africa (at the time of the film it was known as the Belgian Congo, and is now the Democratic Republic of the Congo... you get the idea). The village is burned down by the German occupiers, the missionary dies, and his sister hitches a ride back to civilization with the mail carrier The African Queen, piloted by the hard-drinking Charlie Olnutt (Bogey). Bogey and Hepburn, of course, wind up in a classic romance plot, fighting like cats and dogs until they wind up falling in love.

The beginning of the film is godawfully overacted, mostly by Robert Morley (but the look on Katherine Hepburn's face when she realizes the village is on fire is straight out of a bad silent film). It improves once Bogart and Hepburn are stuck on the boat; Hepburn seems to get more into character, and the chemistry between the two is fabulous. It is, and deserves to be, considered an American classic. ****
My favorite film from the 50's. Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn are a perfect mix together. I now see why it's 100% on the freshness scale, and zero rotten reviews.
HUMPHREY BOGART ONLY OSCAR WINNING ROLE

A romantic comedy disguised as an adventure film with Bogart and Hepburn on the boat ride of their lives. You can't go wrong with the two leads and the direction of John Huston. It is an entertaining journey with 3 legends at the helm. 

Grade: B+

This is the manliest romance I've ever watched. A wonderful adventure movie about a British spinster & a Canadian ship captain sailing an African river on the eve of the Great War, building homemade torpedoes to fight the Germans, & giving in to the inevitable budding romance.

n this movie Katherine Hepburn plays Rosey, a mission girl in Africa in 1914, during a war over the land between Germany and Britain. Humphrey Bogart plays Charlie, a rustic deliveryman who transports supplies on his boat "The African Queen." Together the two set off to escape the battleground traveling along the Ulanga River, devising a plan to overcome the Germans. On their journey thye battle the elements including mosquitos, leeches, rapids and marshy waters. As often is the case in the movies, proximity sparks romance. The plot is rather simplistic and is more about watching this couple survive on an African river. There are no interesting twists in the plot like Anaconda (1997), where the characters go crazy or start turning on each other or anything like that. The movie does have some nice nature photography for the parts filmed on location in Africa, which was probably innovative when the movie came out. This isn't my favorite Bogart role, as I prefer seeing him in more dapper roles, for lack of a better word, like in "The Maltese Falcon" (1941) or "Casablanca" (1942). But this movie does show his ability to play diverse roles, and he did win the Academy Award for Best Actor for this film. Overall a decent classic film, and a essential piece in the Bogart collecion
My favourite Huston film and favourite Bogart film and favourite Katherine Hepburn  film.  I just love watching this film!

I think the film may be a lot sillier than its reputation suggests (that ending is outrageous), but even so I think the utterly perfect pairing of Bogart and Hepburn make it all work. If not for their performances I sincerely doubt anyone would remember this.
An amazing adventure film with awesome performances from Katherine Hepburn and Humphrey Bogart who display real chemistry throughout the film.
Bogart was pretty good, and this had surprisingly strong visuals for being made in the early 50's.

The African Queen is a nice little adventure film with fine cast and some beautiful scenery, but apart from that is not so engaging on other levels and the second half of the film is somewhat weaker than the promising beginning of the film.

"This boat's only big for the two of us."

The American Film Institute named Humphrey Bogart the greatest film actor of all-time. For the greatest actress, the AFI gave that title to Katherine Hepburn. But what happens when you put two highly acclaimed stars, put them in a film made by John Huston (of Maltese Falcon fame) about an unlikely couple teaming up on a boat? Well, what comes out is a delightful, funny, moving, touching, and wonderful drama/comedy/adventure, whatever you call it.

Katherine Hepburn plays Rose Sayer, who lives in Africa during WWI with her missionary brother (Robert Morley). Humphrey Bogart plays Charlie Allnut, the captain of the steam boat The African Queen, who regularly provides African villagers with supplies. When Germans destroy the village and lead to the mad death of the missionary brother, Rose teams up with Charlie and together, ride the African rivers in the boat. At first, Rose can't stand Charlie's ugly looks and drinking problems (in this case, gin), but as the voyage progresses, the two start falling in love and work together to survive the waters and develop ideas to destroy German ships.

John Huston is one of my all-time favorite directors, making such classics as The Maltese Falcon, The Treasure of the Sierra Madre, and Key Largo. The African Queen, on the other hand deserves to join the Huston classics list. Why? Cause it's just so fun to watch.

The African Queen was an introduction to many involved, particularly Huston and Bogart, to the world of Technicolor. The colors are simply beautiful. What helps is the great decision of Huston deciding to film it in Africa itself. The result are colors that wow in every shot and cinematography that takes the breath out of every individual who watches. I particularly enjoyed looking at shots of some of the creatures in Africa; the crocodiles, the hippos, and some deadlier than others.

Everyone knows how talented of an actor Humphrey Bogart is. Bogart delights in films like Casablanca, and even some of Huston's other works that I've already mentioned. Bogart won an Oscar for his role as Charlie the crazy captain of the African Queen, and it's well-deserved. When you think of a good romantic partner for Bogart, you instantly think of ladies like Ingrid Bergman or Lauren Bacall, but here, that lady is Katharine Hepburn. Thankfully, Hepburn is not a miscast and her chemistry with Bogart is strong. I enjoyed the comedic remarks at each other and the romance delivers. 

One little thing against this film, and it's that there's not a huge cast to praise. There's only Bogart, Hepburn, and Robert Morley as the missionary, but Morley was only in the first ten minutes. The best movies have big casts in them, but The African Queen has too few stars. I know I'm knitpicking, but it really bothered me.

I enjoyed the adventurous story, especially in the last 30 minutes or so, where the couple has to survive the jungles. I loved the romantic and comedic aspects of the film. I was wowed by the glorious colors seen in the film. While I was displeased with a lack in a giant cast, which I'll probably have negative votes on, the story and Bogart and Hepburn's performances make up for it, making The African Queen a classic worth watching. While Casablanca and Bringing Up Baby are definitely the definitive films from Bogart and Hepburn, putting the two together was a smart idea, and Huston delivered in making The African Queen a fun film.
One incredibly fun and unforgettable adventure.

Considered a classic, African Queen is a hybrid between action adventure and romantic comedy.  There is little plot in the film, and most of the substance comes from the growing relationship between Bogart's and Hepburn's characters.  The sad part is that while Hepburn's character is a fully developed detailed and interesting character, Bogart's character is little more than a comedic shell, reminiscent of Mary Poppin's Bert.

Since The African Queen was the only film Humphrey Bogart won an Academy Award for acting in and because it featured the efforts of Katharine Hepburn's acting and John Huston's directing I couldn't miss it.

The African Queen is more than obviously a very dated film because it's visual effects leave a clear green outline on the figures in front if the green screen. And is also clearly done on a low budget, and yet it still hits its entertainment value well.
The story in The African Queen is a simple one about an adventure two characters embark on, and it truly has the feel of a classic adventure theme since the atmosphere is intense at times and the musical score feels really convincing to the jungle adventure genre that the film entails. It's not hard to see what makes The African Queen a classic.
Thanks to John Huston's direction it all feels very genuine. The adventure proves to he an interesting one and even a thrilling one in The African Queen, and it is full of fine quality cinematography and beautiful scenery which makes it feel like a real story, even on such a low budget. John Huston's direction proves to carry the thin story in The African Queen a long way, and he makes it a memorable visual experience.
And combined with C. S. Forester's own screenplay adapted on the novel he wrote himself, there ends up being plenty of cleverly conceived material for the cast of The African Queen to work with.
Humphrey Bogart is at some of his most playfully energetic as well and dedicated in The African Queen, and even though his performance isn't the most sophisticated of his career, it still has an amiable charm of life to it in the line delivery he gets right at every second and his iconic smile. Humphrey Bogart carries the story in The African Queen well.
Katharine Hepburn's charm is tenacious as usual in The African Queen, and she has a marvellous spirit and strength to her ensures that Rose Sayer is a fiercely confident character who convincingly charters the waters with  Charlie Allnut in The African Queen. Katharine Hepburn's dedication to character pays off once again, and she proves to work alongside Humphrey Bogart greatly. Her performance is the true greatest of the film and it's some of her most energetic acting, both emotionally and physically.
The chemistry between these two is appealing because there is always a special romantic and dramatic tension between them as they are both aged people taking a journey together which becomes a life changing adventure. Considering that they are considered to be the all time greatest male and female actors, it is no surprise that what happens between them is full of charisma and passion which makes them an amiable duo for The African Queen. The two of them together make a great team and it makes the story of The African Queen very compelling and entertaining to watch, if for nothing else then solely to watch two legendary actors go at it together in an adventure and love story.
Peter Bull's brief role proves effective as well.

So The African Queen is a classic example of a jungle adventure film which has a simple story and an extremely dedicated duo of leads.
Katharine Hepburn has a habit of annoying me, and to begin with this was no exception. As the film went on I warmed to her a lot. This is a cool film, an interesting story with a cracking ending.
un gran duo que cuenta una historia llena de naturalidad y encanto, un clasico merecido
Bogey and Hepburn are the best ever.  Period.

Wonderful film. I have seen it twice and look forward to watching it again. The sweet way that Charlie falls for Rose is something that only two wonderful actors can portray. The scene where Bogart imitates the hippos and makes her laugh is adorable. The wedding is unforgettable.
Fantastic in every meaning of the word.

The chemistry between Bogart and Hepburn is remarkable and inspired. It is a delight to watch the pairing inevitably fall in love, and to stare in awe at the East Africa backdrop which is stunningly photographed.
The African Queen is endearing and well acted, as the powerhouse duo entertain in the static set.
Bogart is brilliant and so is the writing but a bit slow.
The chemistry between Bogart, Hepburn and Huston takes front seat in what may be one of the greatest actor vehicles of all time; certainly one of the most gorgeously shot.
Funny, suspenseful, and moving. Falls just short of the praise that it receives.

Epic and exotic, but I really liked the maturity of the romance: finding the person who finally makes you feel alive, at the worst possible place and time, and not being too proud to see it. Very sweet. (And the Bluray transfer is fantastic).

Charlie Allnut: Oh, I'm not worried miss. Gave myself up for dead back where we started.

"The greatest adventure a man ever lived... with a woman!"

The African Queen is a movie I have wanted to see for a long time. It has the distinction of being one of those classic films that very film fan has to see. On top of that, it stars Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn and is directed by John Huston. So there's really nothing to deter you from wanting to watch it.

When WW1 is launched, a missionary living in Africa with her minister brother, must leave with a rugged, riverboat captain; after her village is destroyed by German soldiers and her brother dies. Rose wants Charlie to go down the river, which worries Charlie a great deal because as he says, there's only death down the river. He reluctantly agrees and the river, as well as a German U-Boat create many obstacles for the missionary and alcoholic captain.

The African Queen wasn't the irrevocable masterpiece a expected, but nonetheless it is still a very good film. I wasn't blown away by anything that the film did, but it was undeniably entertaining and well constructed, written, directed, and acted. The African Queen is a film that needs to be seen by all film buffs.

This movie is pure escapism, but you gotta love it. Katharine Hepburn plays Rose Sayer, a prim and proper missionary in German East Africa with her brother (Robert Morley) in 1914.Suddenly, right after they receive news that war has broken out in Europe, the German army comes in and demolishes their settlement. After the brother dies, hard-drinking stubbly sailor Charlie Allnut (Humphrey Bogart) comes in and agrees to take Rose down the river. Along the way, they bicker about various things (she's disgusted by his drinking, he finds her too pious), but they grow to respect each other.Bogart and Hepburn pretty much play their usual roles, and the movie also stars a few crocodiles (most of the movie was filmed on location in Africa). The portrayal of the German army certainly seems to be an allusion to the Nazis. But overall, the movie is quite admirable, with Rose's and Charlie's personalities bouncing off of each other. It's like an early buddy comedy, even though it's serious.

With the ultimate pairing of Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn, this film throws together two starkly different people in extraordinary circumstances. Hepburn is a prim and proper missionary in Africa whose brother dies after a confrontation with German soldiers. Bogart is the rough-edged pilot of an old steamboat christened The African Queen. Together they take on the dangerous task of going down the river in order to sink a German ship. At first they are both at odds with each other and struggle to cope with their situation. However, with no one else to turn to, over time, they become close. Their bond is so great that they are willing to die rather than to be separated. This is truly a heartwarming story of love and loyalty with two legends who literally light up the screen.

The scenes of Hepburn and Bogart was marvelous and lovely. I was so entertained by them. The only thing I was bothered was the special effects. However, it is an excuse since they are not that advanced then as we are now.

There are so many fine things about this movie that they are hard to innumerate. Filmed on location in the Congo, the cinematography is remarkably fine without being obtrusive; the script, which is at once subtle and very purposeful, has a remarkably natural tone; the two stars--who play the vast majority of the film alone together--give justly famous performances; and Huston's direction is so fine that we never feel even the slightest hint of directorial manipulation.

Excellent film. The highlight of the film is Bogart and Hepburn. Thank goodness that this film is limited to almost a single setting, allowing these two actors to interact throughout the whole film with nobody else interrupting.

A good shepherd doesn't desert his flock when a wolf is prowling.

In Africa during World War 1 a gin swindler and residential mail man informs a local missionary, lead by an English brother and sister, about the German's beginning the first World War.  Shortly after their discussion, the Germans invade the area killing the villagers and brother.  The gin swindler feels bad for the sister and agrees to help her destroy a German vessel using his boat.

"What an absurd idea?  Lady, you have ten absurd ideas to my one."

John Huston, director of The Maltese Falcon, The Treasure of the Sierra Madrid, The Man Who Would be King, Annie, Chinatown (1974), and Casino Royale (1967), delivers African Queen.  The storyline for this picture is very good and well thought out.  There are quite a few scenes that are a stretch but remain fun to watch unfold.  The acting is awesome and the cast includes Humphrey Bogart, Katherine Hepburn, Robert Morley, Peter Bull, and Theodore Bikel.    

"I should hang you twice I think."

I recently watched this picture on Netflix since this was another Humphrey Bogart gem I had never seen.  I am a huge fan of both Bogart and Hepburn and found there back and forth wonderful.  The storyline definitely seemed unrealistic but fun to watch each character drive the other throughout the film.  I recommend seeing this picture but it may not be your favorite Bogart or Hepburn picture.

"I'll parish without some hair of the dog."

Grade: B+
Great movie ,I have seen several times.
Fun and light-hearted. Maybe a little hokey at times.
Two annoying people fall in love with each other. IN AFRICA! Eh.
Not quite what I was expecting. :)
Well acted and superbly shot, The African Queen gets dry at times, but overall is Bogart and Hepburn at their best.
T his is the Godfather of all Romance films-simply a classic

I love this movie! It's a Hepburn-Bogart classic and since the 2 number 1 screen legends of the American Film Institute (AFI) this is my second favorite Bogie movie of all time my favorite is Casablanca!!! ð~
Wonderful movie! I love Humprey Bogart!

Filled with adventure, romance, drama, comedy, there is no shortage of variety in this John Huston-helmed smorgasbord of classic cinematic themes. Adapted from the popular 1935 C.S. Forester novel, "The African Queen" showcases an early 1900s East African scene in the beginning of the World War I German occupation. Humphrey Bogart earned his gold starring as a man's man of a goofball river boat captain who picks up a stranded English missionary (Katherine Hepburn) after the village she was helping is decimated. Together they embark on a mission down the windy African rivers where they fight off the elements, the enclosing Germans, and their cheeky feelings for one another. All of this culminating with the task of turning the captain's boat, "The African Queen" into a large torpedo aimed directly at an enemy warship that is stalking one of the larger lakes in the area. . . For its time, the film is one helluva spectacle and sported some of the early stages of when films were transitioning to color. This obviously enhanced the main point of the film, which was to really show off the wonders of the African jungle. What really stole the show though was ol "Bogie", who usually so calm and charming, turned himself into the most likable "Gilligan"-esque dweeb ever to navigate such a treacherous scene with a damsel on his arm. Hepburn reciprocates this by portraying the sheltered church girl awakened by adventure and acts accordingly in a just as awkward way. They swoon for each other the way a child goes for their teddy bear. It's innocent and trades off with sweet as well as cheesy with just a hint of danger to keep the audience guessing. . . 
Humphrey "Bogie" Bogart's Grade: B (I still prefer him in the more suave roles)

Film Grade: B
I was watching this movie and love it.

"The African Queen" isn't as impressive as it could have been, but it's still a worthwhile romance flick, although underwritten. The main reason it's worth seeing is that Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn act opposite one another and display likable chemistry, delivering their lines with a good amount of gusto. There are also some great on-location shots and well-edited sequences, but disappointingly, not much else.
One of John Huston's most ambitious films, featuring the legendary pairing of Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn, The African Queen is a smart, thrilling and memorable adventure classic.
I can't believe how many people HAVEN'T seen this classic!

Rose (Katharine Hepburn) is a prim missionary whose African labors are abruptly waylaid by the outbreak of World War I. Her salvation from German forces comes in Charlie (Humphrey Bogart), a roughneck captain of a tramp steamer dubbed The African Queen. Danger and adventure break out when Rose, much to Charlie's gin-soaked chagrin, decides to use this modest vessel to attack the dominant German warship in the region. This film, directed with John Huston's usual economy, is an amiable and inviting mixture of matinee-style action and Hollywood-style romance. While it has other charms, its principle strength lies in how well Hepburn and Bogart play off each other.
Great outing for both Hepburn and Bogart. The Film is also skillfully directed and filmed.
Love this movie.  Bogey is fantastic again.  This movie will make you laugh and make you cry.  The length is perfect.  A must see and then watch it again

It is difficult to understand the opinion of most that this movie is a classic.  While the cinematography captures a locale not previously so detailed at the time, the value of a movie comes not only in its flash, but its substance.  This was the worst chemistry, acting, dialogue and painfully long story I've ever been made to endure since walking out of "Dune" in the late 80's. I did not buy the transition of these characters from strangers to lovers, especially given the supposed spiritual roots of Katherine Hepburn's character. The most excitement happened during the rafting scenes, which comprised about 5 total minutes of the 1 hour, 45 minute snoozefest. It's an unbelievable premise with main character dialogue that seemed completely unnaturally forced and purposeful. Once of the most overrated films I've ever seen.

During the making, most of the production crew became ill with dysentery. Actor Humphrey Bogart & Director John Huston drank heavily, avoiding water, keeping them free from dysentery. Who said drinking was bad for you!

The African Queen stars the biggest stars of the Classical Hollywood period and it doesn't disappoint. It's a wonderful film that is carried by a good plot and all-star acting by its two leading actors, which carries the film.
Ridiculous and dated, but, it has the charm of that old timing innocence.
Once again, like Sierra Madre, Bogart does have better films. But the play between him and Katherine (my second favorite Hepburn) do enlighten the movie past a simple history tale.
Bogie and Kate come on...

The movie may be shot in a boat but it feels realistic  thanks to a wonderful script. Everything they do has a believable feel to it. Katherine Hepburn's character of a stubborn and fun loving character makes the movie more special.

La Reyna Africana (1951) dir. por John Houston. Magnificas actuaciones de Humphrey Bogart y Katharine Hepburn en los estelares de una pelicula de los a#os 50s que se ha convertido en leyenda. La sola filmacion de la cinta es contada en mas de 7 libros (uno escrito por la propia Hepburn). La fotografia es igualmente esquisita. Es la historia de un capitan de un barco que el da a la bebida y una estirada y puritana misionera que huye de las tropas alemanas al comenzar la 1a Guerra Mundial. Surcaran un rio a bordo de una peque#a embarcacion de vapor (The African Queen), y son precisamente los problemas y penalidades que pasan a bordo del African Queen lo que hara que cambien radicalmente su relacion.

Bogie and Hepburn. I could simply leave it at that. They are the entire movie, with only a few lines and appearances by any other humans. Humphrey Bogart won his only Oscar in 3 noms, and Katharine Hepburn was nominated one of her 12 times.  John Huston directs the 2 legends in their only film together, adapted from the CS Forester novel, in a trip down an African river at the start of WWI. Shot mostly on location in Africa, it's a triumph of the human spirit and will (and luck) as well as a romance. A classic, 60 yrs later, just as popular.
A classic, its smart, funny and sweet all at the same time.
The African Queen's effects may seem a dated, but it did come out in the early 50s', but the performances from the leading actor and actress, Bogart and Hepburn, make this movie a great little joy.
1001 movies to see before you die.
It was such a great movie, it was going to be a masterpiece...and then the ending hit. D'oh.
I've always had great admiration for Bogart and Hepburn, and this film shows why they deserve it.
The #1 male and female movie star respectively on AFI's list, Humphrey Bogart and Katherine Hepburn shine in this charming adventure film.

John Huston filmed his World War I epic on location, which was an unusual decision at the time, but the grittiness and festering of the jungle perfectly matches the griminess of our main characters, played by Bogart and Hepburn.

"the african queen" is essentially just humphrey bogart and katharine hepburn alone together on a boat. but the dialogue and chemistry between the two actors is superb, with great direction from john huston. this is a must see for all classic film lovers.

With such a legendary cast and crew, I'm suprised that this film wasn't brilliant. There is of course, the fact the film was in fact lucky enough to have this troupe of people in in, which gives it some merit. I was initially startled to see Bogart in colour, as i'm more familiar with his 'film noir' works. It was almost silly to see a distinguished actor such as Hepburn play such a naive character. However. with the fantastic direction by John Huston, a relatively simple story gains suspense and excitement and relatively unlikely pair shares convincing chemistry. With more than enough merits, this film is well worth a watch!
Hm, don't see why people liked it, found it overrated and boring

Set in the dangerous, enormously hot and distressingly exotic grounds (or rather waters) of Easterm Africa, this thrilling adventure classic offers one of the most fabulous onscreen relationships in the history. The chemistry between Humphrey Bogart and Katherine Hepburn is indisputable, the dialogues are humorous and engaging, and the cinematography of the far-flung place is simply stunning. Even though most of the plot occurs on board of the African Queen and concers the two main stars, it's packed with tender romance, smooth action, and shocking revelations. John Huston created one of the finest War dramas of the 50's.
Bogie and Hepburn are terrifically matched in this fun and exciting tale.
Two legends of american cinema combines with a great director and finally they all delivers a great picture .
